subject: Re: [junit] Proposed parameterized test syntax for JUnit 4
msgSnippet: ... In my experience, it s pretty rare to see the same test take either a very short time or a very long time depending on the data you give it. Typically, the
messageBody:
On 10/3/05, Eugene Kuleshov <eu@...> wrote:
>
>
> Ok. I may have several data sets (e.g. small one for smoke testing and
> a really huge one for complete regression testing) and I want to choose
> between them from the runner. For instance:
>
> @Parameters(name="smoke") public static Object[] data() {
> return new int[][] {{0, 0}, {1, 1}};
> }
>
> @Parameters(name="full") public static Object[] data() {
> // load data from external file or generate permutations
> return data;
> }
>
> Then you'll specify test type "smoke" or "full" on a runner and it
> will choose an appropriate set of the test data.


In my experience, it's pretty rare to see the same test take either a very
short time or a very long time depending on the data you give it.

Typically, the "smoke" group and the "full" group will contain different
test methods (and the intersection, it not empty, will be made of quick
tests).

Having said that, I obviously agree with you that supporting parameters for
test methods is necessary to improve isolation (something that is done
poorly right now by JUnit3 and the parameterized test case pattern since you
are exposing all the parameters to all the test methods, whether they need
it or not).


--
Cédric
